01-01.event: The ARPANET officially adopted TCP/IP — the protocol that became the foundation of the modern internet.

01-07.event: Apple Computer go public on the stock market, creating more millionaires in a single day than any company in history up to that point.

01-09.event: Steve Jobs unveils the first iPhone at Macworld — calling it 'an iPod, a phone, and an internet communicator' all in one device.

01-24.event: Apple introduces the Macintosh personal computer with the iconic '1984' Super Bowl ad. It features a graphical interface and mouse — radical for its time.

02-07.event: The first Macintosh goes on sale to the public for $2,495 — the equivalent of about $7,500 today.

02-14.event: YouTube.com is registered as a domain name by three former PayPal employees. The first video uploaded is 'Me at the zoo' — 18 seconds long.

02-18.event: Vannevar Bush begins work at MIT on the Differential Analyzer — one of the first practical analog computers.

02-22.event: Dolly the sheep — the first mammal cloned from an adult somatic cell — is revealed to the public, igniting global debates about biotechnology ethics.
Twitter is founded internally at Odeo, a struggling podcasting company. Jack Dorsey sends the first tweet: 'just setting up my twttr'.

03-01.event: Texas Instruments announces the first commercial silicon transistor, enabling miniaturization that would lead to every modern chip.

03-12.event: Tim Berners-Lee submits his proposal for the World Wide Web to CERN. His supervisor writes 'Vague but exciting' on the cover page.

03-22.event: Intel releases the Pentium processor — the first chip to use the brand name instead of a number, because numbers couldn't be trademarked.

04-01.event: Apple Computer Company is founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne. Wayne sells his 10% share for $800 — worth roughly $95 billion today.

04-04.event: Bill Gates and Paul Allen found Microsoft in Albuquerque, New Mexico — named from 'microcomputer software'.

04-07.event: IBM announces the System/360 mainframe — the first computer family designed with compatibility across models, revolutionizing business computing.

04-23.event: The very first YouTube video is uploaded: 'Me at the zoo' by co-founder Jawed Karim. It is still live today.

05-01.event: Douglas Engelbart's team at SRI begins work on the oN-Line System (NLS), which will later demonstrate the mouse, hyperlinks, and collaborative editing — decades ahead of their time.

05-22.event: Laszlo Hanyecz pays 10,000 Bitcoin for two Papa John's pizzas — the first real-world commercial Bitcoin transaction. May 22 is now 'Bitcoin Pizza Day'.

06-04.event: The first Ariane 5 rocket launches — and explodes 37 seconds after liftoff due to a software integer overflow bug. The bug cost $370 million USD.

06-29.event: The original iPhone goes on sale. Within 74 hours, over 270,000 units are sold.

07-01.event: Sony releases the Walkman in Japan — the first truly personal music device. Engineers who saw the prototype said it would never sell because it had no recording function.

07-04.event: NASA's Mars Pathfinder roverlander touches down on Mars. The onboard software — written partially in C — had to be patched in space to fix a priority inversion bug discovered after launch.

07-09.event: William Shockley founds Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory in Mountain View, CA — the first semiconductor company in what will become Silicon Valley.

07-16.event: Apollo 11 launches from Kennedy Space Center carrying Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins toward the Moon.

07-20.event: Neil Armstrong becomes the first human to walk on the Moon. The Apollo Guidance Computer had 4KB of RAM — less than a modern digital watch.

08-06.event: Tim Berners-Lee publishes the first website at CERN. It describes the World Wide Web project. The page is still live at info.cern.ch.

08-12.event: IBM releases the IBM Personal Computer (IBM PC) — running MS-DOS licensed from Microsoft. It legitimizes the personal computer for business use.

08-24.event: Windows 95 launches with a $300 million marketing campaign featuring the Rolling Stones' 'Start Me Up'. Over a million copies sell in the first 4 days.

09-04.event: Google is officially incorporated by Larry Page and Sergey Brin in a Menlo Park garage. Its mission: 'to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible'.

09-13.event: IBM ships the RAMAC 305 with its 350 Disk Storage Unit — the world's first hard disk drive. It weighs 971kg and stores 5 megabytes.

09-30.event: The first numerical weather prediction is run on ENIAC — the calculation takes 24 hours to simulate 24 hours of weather. Today, global weather models run in minutes.

10-04.event: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1 — the first artificial satellite. Its radio beep can be heard by anyone with a shortwave receiver. The Space Age begins.

10-22.event: Douglas Engelbart demonstrates the mouse to the public for the first time, alongside hypertext, video conferencing, and collaborative editing — all in one 90-minute session called 'The Mother of All Demos'.

10-29.event: The first message is sent over ARPANET — the precursor to the internet. The message was supposed to be 'login'. The system crashed after 'lo'. The internet's first two letters were 'lo'.

11-01.event: UNIVAC correctly predicts Eisenhower's landslide election victory using early returns — the first time a computer is used to analyze and predict election results on live TV.

11-09.event: Gary Kildall writes PL/M — the first high-level programming language designed for microprocessors. Kildall later writes CP/M, the operating system IBM almost chose instead of DOS.

11-12.event: Tim Berners-Lee formally proposes a hypertext system to manage CERN documentation. The document that changes the world is titled 'WorldWideWeb: Proposal for a HyperText Project'.

11-30.event: OpenAI launches ChatGPT publicly. In 5 days: 1 million users. In 2 months: 100 million — the fastest consumer product adoption in history.

12-09.event: Douglas Engelbart demonstrates the first computer mouse, hyperlinks, and real-time collaborative editing in 'The Mother of All Demos' at the Fall Joint Computer Conference in San Francisco.

12-23.event: Bell Labs scientists John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley demonstrate the first working transistor. It replaces vacuum tubes and enables all modern electronics.
